settings.instructions:
Overview

This is the INL1Quiz for the Randomness lecture. You must get 100% to pass the course. You can retake it. I recommend that you attempt it before the corresponding lecture and then retake it again afterwards.

Grading

If you fail, you will have to go study a bit more and complement your answers. There is a one hour cool-down between attempts. You must have 100% correct answers to pass. Questions will not give partial credit, you get either full score or none.

I suggest that you write down a short motivation for each answer, such that you can review them for the next attempt.

There is no deadline. (Well, the deadline is when you want to get the grade. When all INL1 assignments have a passing grade in Canvas, they'll be automatically transferred to LADOK. This is done once a week, then there might be a few days delay since one of us will have to see the email notification and go certify the results---i.e. click OK---manually in LADOK.)

entry.title: Entropy and randomness
entry.item_body: Check all statements that are true about entropy and randomness.

choices.item_body: Entropy measures the unpredictability (uncertainty) in a random variable.
A uniform distribution over N outcomes has maximum entropy of log2(N) bits.
A biased coin (99% heads) has higher entropy than a fair coin.
If a random variable always produces the same value, its entropy is zero.
A source with high entropy is more predictable than one with low entropy.

entry.title: TRNG vs PRNG
entry.item_body: Check all statements that are true about True Random Number Generators (TRNGs) and Pseudo-Random Number Generators (PRNGs).

choices.item_body: A TRNG derives randomness from physical processes (thermal noise, radioactive decay).
A PRNG is a deterministic algorithm that produces a sequence from an initial seed.
Given the same seed, a PRNG will always produce the same output sequence.
TRNGs are always faster than PRNGs, which is why they are preferred in high-throughput applications.
A PRNG can pass statistical randomness tests even though it is fully determined by its seed.
A TRNG does not need post-processing because physical sources always produce perfectly uniform distributions.

entry.title: Cryptographically secure PRNGs
entry.item_body: Check all statements that are true about cryptographically secure pseudo-random number generators (CSPRNGs).

choices.item_body: A CSPRNG must produce output computationally indistinguishable from true random bits.
Any PRNG that passes the NIST statistical test suite is automatically cryptographically secure.
A CSPRNG must satisfy the next-bit test: given k bits, no polynomial-time algorithm can predict bit k+1 with probability significantly greater than 1/2.
If a CSPRNG's internal state is compromised, past outputs should still remain unpredictable (backtracking resistance).
Cryptographic security of a PRNG means it will never repeat its output sequence.

entry.title: Seeding and entropy sources
entry.item_body: Check all statements that are true about seeding pseudo-random number generators.

choices.item_body: The security of a CSPRNG depends critically on the seed having sufficient entropy.
Using the current time as the sole seed for a CSPRNG is generally secure, because time always changes.
Operating systems typically gather entropy from multiple sources (keyboard timing, disk I/O, hardware noise) to seed their RNG.
If an attacker determines the seed, they can reproduce the entire CSPRNG output.
Reseeding periodically with fresh entropy mitigates the impact of a state compromise.
A CSPRNG with a 256-bit seed always provides 256 bits of security, regardless of how the seed was generated.

entry.title: Weak PRNGs
entry.item_body: Check all statements that are true about linear congruential generators (LCGs) and other non-cryptographic PRNGs.

choices.item_body: An LCG computes xn+1 = (a · xn + c) mod m for fixed constants a, c, m.
LCGs are fast and simple, suitable for non-cryptographic applications like simulations.
LCGs are cryptographically secure because their long period length makes output unpredictable.
Given a few consecutive LCG outputs, an attacker can determine the parameters and predict all future values.
The Mersenne Twister is suitable for cryptographic key generation because it has a very long period.

entry.title: Hardware RNGs
entry.item_body: Check all statements that are true about hardware and physical random number generators.

choices.item_body: HWRNGs based on quantum phenomena (e.g. shot noise) can in principle provide true randomness.
A HWRNG's raw output should typically pass through conditioning (whitening) to remove bias.
The main advantage of a HWRNG over a PRNG is throughput: hardware generators produce bits much faster.
Heuristic random generators gather entropy from unpredictable system events (interrupt timing, network jitter) rather than a dedicated hardware source.
An important reason to use a HWRNG to seed a PRNG rather than using the HWRNG directly is that the PRNG can supply bits at higher rate without depleting the entropy pool.

entry.title: Randomness in cryptographic protocols
entry.item_body: Check all statements that are true about the role of randomness in cryptographic protocols.

choices.item_body: Randomness is essential for key generation: if an attacker can narrow down the possible keys, brute-force becomes feasible.
Many encryption schemes (CBC mode, RSA-OAEP) require fresh random values per operation; reusing them can compromise security.
In Diffie–Hellman, each party chooses a random secret exponent. If the RNG is compromised, an eavesdropper can compute the shared secret.
A nonce used in a protocol does not need to be random as long as it is unique; therefore a simple counter is always a safe choice.
If a digital signature scheme derives per-signature randomness deterministically from the message and key (RFC 6979), it avoids the failure mode of a broken RNG.
Sony's PS3 ECDSA key was compromised because the implementation reused the same random nonce k for every signature, allowing the private key to be computed.
Using a constant initialization vector (IV) in AES-CTR mode is safe as long as the key is changed for each message.
A cryptographically secure PRNG is designed so that even if part of its internal state or output is revealed, its past and future values should remain unpredictable.
Even a strong CSPRNG can become insecure if seeded with insufficient entropy or predictable values.
Simple deterministic methods like elementary LCGs may pass basic statistical tests but are not considered cryptographically secure.
Proper seeding using high-entropy inputs is critical; without it, even a well-designed PRNG can be compromised.
If one has access to a HWRNG, one should only use that. It's much more secure than a PRNG.
If one has access to a HWRNG, one should use that to seed a PRNG. Using the PRNG helps from depleting the entropy pool in the HWRNG.
